answers.answer: Pain is not a common symptoms with your thyroid history.  However the goal TSH is 0.3-2.5 - so a dose increase would not be unreasonable, but is unlikely to help.Given the other antibodies, would look for Addison's.  True Adrenal Insufficiency (Addison's) can cause muscle symptoms and would be important to consider.

question: Hi Dr Lupo,I had my thyroid ablated a little over two years ago due to hashitoxicosis. I have lost about 4 pounds through this time and my hair is not falling out anymore. The pain and muscle weakness has been pretty constant for three years steady. I am on 200 synthroid since February, I was increased slowly, my last labs were  TSH 2.75 so no dose change. My Endo agrees I will have good and bad days...but is the pain something that is normal with this type of autoimmune? I have hust been checked for systemic collagen vascular disorders the bloodwork came back ok. Also bone scan for oste was ok. I am 45 and peri-menopausal. I have pre-diabetes with type1 antibodies, and tested positive for anti-parietal antibodies, negative for celiac sprue. Could the combination of all the antibodies be causing the pain, or would you think just the thyroid being ablated?
title: Two Years Post Ablation
